entry.title: Older swimmers embrace numbing cold by plunging straight into ice water in China
entry.summary: Each year, in the freezing provincial capital of Harbin, in China, people plunge straight into near freezing water. What's more, it's usually the seniors who excel.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Trump has a China problem in Venezuela: What to do with Beijing‚Äôs debt and oil stakes
entry.summary: President Donald Trump‚Äôs plan to control Venezuela's oil industry and counter China's influence could clash with his goal of stabilizing trade with Beijing.

entry.title: Countries and industries most exposed to Trump's IEEPA-based tariffs
entry.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court is set to issue rulings on Friday on cases related to the legality of tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.

entry.title: Trump says Venezuela does not give China a Taiwan precedent, but 'it's up to' Xi
entry.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump said "it‚Äôs up to" Chinese President Xi Jinping what China does on Taiwan, but that he would be "very unhappy" with a change in the status quo, according to an interview the New York Times published on Thursday.

entry.title: Trading Day: Defense over tech, payrolls next
entry.summary: Global stocks mostly fell, while oil and Treasury yields rose on Thursday, as investors reacted nervously to U.S. President Donald Trump's call for a huge increase in defense spending and awaited key U.S. employment figures on Friday.

entry.title: 'If it expires, it expires,' Trump tells NYT about US-Russia nuclear treaty
entry.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump indicated he would allow the last U.S.-Russia strategic arms control treaty to expire without accepting an offer from Moscow to voluntarily extend its caps on deployments of the world's most powerful nuclear weapons, according to remarks released on Thursday.

entry.title: Qualcomm to provide infotainment tech for new Volkswagen platform
entry.summary: Volkswagen plans a long-term supply deal with U.S. chip designer Qualcomm to deliver infotainment technology for the German carmaker's new software platform.

entry.title: The mission to keep the borderlands wild
entry.summary:
To appreciate how¬†the Madrean Sky Islands earn their nickname, it helps to imagine the hawk‚Äôs-eye view. Looking down over the borderlands that stretch out across Arizona, New Mexico, and the Mexican states of Sonora and Chihuahua, you would see a wide swath of desert scattered with more than 50 small, rugged mountain ranges: an archipelago of green on either side of the international border.
These high-country oases help make the Sky Islands region one of the world‚Äôs most spectacularly biodiverse, a place where a fleet-footed mammal might wander among five different biomes in a day, from dusty desert scrub to lush pine and fir forests. And for millennia, wild creatures of all sorts‚Äîjavelinas and pronghorn, coyotes and ocelots, black bears and jaguars‚Äîhave moved across this land by fol‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside a remote cave where tarantulas are as big as dinner plates
entry.summary: In episode 2 of Pole to Pole, Will Smith captures a tarantula in a cave in Ecuador in order to study it with scientists. In his new National Geographic series Pole to Pole, the actor ventures deep into the Amazon in search of creatures whose venom may yield new life-saving drugs. Under the hot sun of the high Andes, a team of scientists, local guides, and a movie star trudges downhill on a dirt path. Their long, slippery walk through the Amazon Rainforest ends at Tayos Cave, a massive underground system. The crew rigs up ropes and descends close to 300 feet, the equivalent of a 20-story building. There, in the pitch black, they will seek out venomous creatures‚Äîscorpions, centipedes, and spiders‚Äîincluding an unidentified tarantula the size of a dinner plate. ¬† ‚ÄúIt‚Ä¶

entry.title: What you should know about taking prescription drugs off-label
entry.summary:
As telehealth and direct-to-consumer pharmacy services grow more common, prescription drugs are becoming easier to access. Some consumers are increasingly exploring these medications as part of a broader approach to preventive health. Medications once used to treat illness are increasingly being taken for prevention. Experts explain what‚Äôs behind the shift‚Äîand what the science actually supports.
When Deborah M. Kado attends cocktail parties, she says people ask her all the time about what medications they ‚Äúshould‚Äù be taking or what she thinks about certain prescription medications used for longevity. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a soft biohacker,‚Äù says Kado, a medical doctor, professor of geriatric medicine, and co-director of the Stanford Longevity Center. ‚ÄúFrom the beginning of humanity, people have bee‚Ä¶

entry.title: Route 66 at 100: Visit the end of road in sunny Santa Monica
entry.summary:
A century after Route 66 officially opened in 1926, the road‚Äôs final stretch through Los Angeles County, from Pasadena to Santa Monica‚Äôs golden sands, remains wonderfully in tact.
Long before John Steinbeck dubbed Route 66 "The Mother Road" in his 1930s dustbowl novel The Grapes of Wrath, the Indigenous Tongva and Chumash people forged trade routes along the paths Route 66 takes through California‚Äôs Mojave Desert and into the still genteel urban landscape of Pasadena, where it becomes Colorado Boulevard.
By the late 1920s, to accommodate growing traffic, storefronts were shaved off to widen parts of Colorado, and were then rebuilt in popular styles of the day, including art deco, Spanish Revival, and Beaux-Arts.
Julia Long of Pasadena Walking Tours points out that in 1930 an‚Ä¶

entry.title: I hiked into Arizona's Grand Canyon‚Äîhere's what it was like
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
One-armed, lavishly bearded and as tough as bedrock, John Wesley Powell was the leader of the first river passage through the Grand Canyon. The geologist and explorer wrote extensively about his expedition in 1869, concluding: ‚ÄòYou cannot see the Grand Canyon in one view, as if it were a changeless spectacle from which a curtain might be lifted. To see it, you have to toil from month to month through its labyrinths.‚Äô
It‚Äôs in this spirit ‚Äî if not quite this timeframe ‚Äî that I arrive in Arizona‚Äôs foremost national park. I‚Äôm hiking the Escalante Route: a four-day circuit that snakes all the way down to the banks of the mighty Colorado River from the South Rim, the entry point to the canyon for the vast majority of vis‚Ä¶

entry.title: US, China can balance roles in Venezuela, US energy chief says

entry.title: Myanmar vote a ‚Äòfacade‚Äô to entrench military rule, independent rights expert says
entry.summary: An independent human rights expert has urged the international community to reject the electoral process organised by Myanmar‚Äôs military government, after the first round of voting revealed widespread coercion, exclusion and violence.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid continues despite winter hardship in Gaza and West Bank, UN says
entry.summary: Despite harsh winter conditions and continuing access constraints, the UN and partners are maintaining large-scale humanitarian operations in Gaza and the occupied West Bank, with a focus on shelter, water, health and education.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres continues to be gravely alarmed by escalating hostilities in Aleppo, Syria, and mounting reports of civilian casualties, his Spokesperson said on Thursday.

entry.title: Ukraine: New strikes disrupt basic services for millions
entry.summary: Several parts of Ukraine were hit by a new wave of Russian strikes between Wednesday and Thursday morning.

entry.title: Syria signals renewed cooperation on chemical weapons destruction
entry.summary: Progress continues to be made towards eliminating remnants of the chemical weapons programme in Syria that was developed under the Assad regime, the UN Security Council heard on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global economy shows signs of steady but subdued growth
entry.summary: The global economy has shown resilience amid turbulence during the past year, including shifting trade policies ‚Äì yet growth remains subdued and far below pre-pandemic levels, the UN said in a landmark report published on Thursday.

entry.summary: Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has expressed regret over the decision by the United States to withdraw from a number of UN entities, while underscoring that the system will continue to deliver on all its mandates.

entry.title: Human Rights Council elects Indonesian candidate President for 2026
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Council ‚Äì the world‚Äôs principal defender of vulnerable people worldwide ‚Äì has elected an Indonesian diplomat to be President for 2026 in a first for the country.

entry.title: Importers brace for $150 billion tariff refund fight if Trump loses at Supreme Court
entry.summary: Company executives, customs brokers and trade lawyers are bracing for a Supreme Court ruling on the legality of President Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs - and a potential fight over obtaining perhaps $150 billion in refunds from the U.S. government for duties already paid by importers if he loses.

entry.title: China to probe Meta‚Äôs acquisition of artificial intelligence startup Manus
entry.summary: China's commerce ministry says it plans to investigate Meta's acquisition of AI startup Manus. Meta, the tech giant behind Facebook and Instagram, announced last week that it was buying Manus, a Singapore-based company with Chinese roots, to boost AI offerings across its platforms.

entry.title: US container imports dropped 5.9% in December on continued China slump, Descartes says
entry.summary: U.S. container imports fell 5.9% in December to end the year down 0.4% from 2024 after President Donald Trump's tariff policies slashed shipments from China, shook up global trade and fueled inflation fears, supply chain technology provider Descartes Systems Group said on Thursday.

entry.title: French aerospace frets over political 'weaponisation' of global supply chains
entry.summary: France's aerospace industry expressed concern over the "weaponisation" of global supply chains as major powers pursue their geopolitical agendas, and warned that rare earths remained a pressure point despite a U.S.-China trade truce.

entry.title: China TV shows alleged 'scam centre' kingpin handcuffed and hooded after surprise arrest
entry.summary: Chinese television showed footage of U.S.-indicted tycoon Chen Zhi being escorted by armed police after his extradition to China from Cambodia, where authorities on Thursday ordered the liquidation of a bank he founded linked to a massive "scam centre" network.

entry.title: Exclusive: India plans to scrap curbs on Chinese firms bidding for government contracts
entry.summary: India's finance ministry plans to scrap five-year-old restrictions on Chinese firms bidding for government contracts, two government sources said, as New Delhi seeks to revive commercial ties in an environment of reduced border tensions.

entry.title: China and Japan, uneasy neighbors in East Asia, are at odds again
entry.summary: They‚Äôre at it again. China and Japan are frenemies, trading partners and uneasy neighbors with a tortured and bloody history they‚Äôre still working through.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: China says it will release more details about extradition case from Cambodia
entry.summary: China said on Thursday it will release more information related to the extradition of an individual named Chen Zhi from Cambodia, without confirming the person's whereabouts or if he is the same person sanctioned by the U.S. and Britain, accused of operating large online scam centres.

entry.title: China to assess, investigate Meta's acquisition of AI startup Manus
entry.summary: China will assess and investigate Meta's acquisition of artificial intelligence startup Manus, the Chinese commerce ministry said on Thursday.

entry.title: China says ban on exports of dual-use items to Japan to only hit military companies
entry.summary: China's export ban on dual-use items to Japan will only affect military firms, the commerce ministry said on Thursday, helping calm fears that Beijing might curb rare-earth shipments vital to Japan's automotive industry over Tokyo's remarks on Taiwan.

entry.title: China against 'political disinformation' about US government email breach
entry.summary: China on Thursday said it was against "politically motivated disinformation" in relation to reports of Chinese hackers targeting staff in United States congressional committees in an email breach.

entry.title: Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing hikes annual forecast after surge in quarterly profit
entry.summary: The operator of the Uniqlo clothing brand, Japan's Fast Retailing , said quarterly operating profit surged by a third and it bumped up its annual outlook, citing robust sales growth globally that helped it absorb U.S. tariffs.

entry.title: Exclusive: Nvidia requires full upfront payment for H200 chips in China
entry.summary: Nvidia is requiring full upfront payment from Chinese customers seeking its H200 artificial intelligence chips, hedging it against ongoing uncertainty over Beijing's approval of the shipments, said two people briefed on the matter.

entry.title: European defence stocks hit record high, dollar gains amid geopolitical events
entry.summary: European defence stocks jumped to a record high and oil prices and the dollar both made ground on Thursday, as geopolitical developments from Venezuela to Greenland kept traders guessing.

entry.title: Dollar rises versus euro and Swiss franc with markets eyeing US jobs report
entry.summary: The dollar gained against the euro and Swiss franc on Thursday, as investors awaited Friday‚Äôs crucial nonfarm payrolls report, which could help assess the U.S. labor market and the probable path of interest rates.

entry.title: World‚Äôs first physically growing AI-powered pocket pet unveiled at CES 2026
entry.summary: China-based Takway‚Äôs Sweekar pocket pet uses artificial intelligence to change and grow with its owner, slowly emerging from its egg-style casing.

entry.title: US exempts some foreign-made drones from Trump import ban on new models
entry.summary: The U.S. Federal Communications Commission said on Wednesday it is exempting imports of some new models of foreign-made drones and critical components from a sweeping import ban adopted in December.

entry.title: TRADING DAY Sunny start, gloomy end
entry.summary: The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrials climbed to new highs on Wednesday but closed the session lower in the wake of patchy U.S. employment data, while bond yields, oil, and metals prices also posted notable declines.

entry.title: Prime Minister Mark Carney to visit China next week as Canada pivots away from the US
entry.summary: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney will visit China next week where he will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping as Canada looks to reduce its over reliance on the United States.

entry.title: White House says Greenland purchase is an active discussion, Trump is committed to NATO
entry.summary: President Donald Trump remains committed to the NATO alliance even as he and his national security team are holding active discussions about a U.S. purchase of Greenland, White House spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Cambodia extradites alleged scam kingpin Chen Zhi to China
entry.summary: Cambodia‚Äôs government has arrested and extradited prominent tycoon Chen Zhi to China. Chen allegedly led a massive online scam operation and was wanted by U.S. authorities.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: China's Dongfeng in talks to produce passenger cars in Turkey, local distributor says
entry.summary: China's Dongfeng Motor is in talks with an investor about producing passenger cars in Turkey, the company's Turkish distributor said.

entry.title: Love in a cold climate - dozens of couples say ‚ÄòI do‚Äô at Harbin Ice Festival
entry.summary: The Harbin ice wedding is a signature event held during the Harbin International Ice and Snow Festival, where 42 couples exchange vows with backdrops of ice and snow.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: How to explore the tropical side of Japan in Okinawa
entry.summary:
The traditional Okinawan sabani boats were historically used for fishing and travelling between islands. With its laid-back seafaring culture and unique wildlife, the Yaeyama archipelago in Japan‚Äôs far southern Okinawa prefecture reveals a different side to Japan.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
It‚Äôs show time. Up heaves the sail, a concertina of heavy canvas pulled taut against the creaking wooden mast. It gulps the breeze that‚Äôs whisking cotton puffs of cloud out to sea. Black butterflies, big as sparrows, rise from the steep jungle at our backs as the droning of cicadas meets the surf raking the beach. The air is flower-scented, hot and heavy as water. Up comes the anchor, out come the paddles; the nose of the traditional sabani boat plung‚Ä¶

entry.title: How scientists learn from the masters of invisibility: Octopus
entry.summary: Cephalopods like the giant Pacific octopus (Enteroctopus dofleini) are masters of camouflage. As researchers gain a better understanding of how these animals hide in plain sight, they're also trying to harness octopus tricks for human technologies. Octopus and other cephalopods are good at hiding themselves‚Äîand are inspiring cutting-edge technologies that may help us do the same. When it comes to near-invisibility, the world champions may be the octopus and other cephalopods, which can shift their color and texture on cue to become virtually indistinguishable from their surroundings. As an octopus glides across sand, tucks itself between rock‚Ä¶

entry.title: When was Pompeii really destroyed? Experts can‚Äôt seem to agree.
entry.summary:
The ancient city of Herculanum was destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius. This 19th-century painting shows the inhabitants who came to take refuge on a hill. The true date of the eruption has long eluded‚Äîand vexed‚Äîhistorians of the deadly disaster. Here‚Äôs what the archaeological evidence tells us.
On August 24, A.D. 79, a Roman teenager witnessed a horrible sight: a telltale cloud rising from Mount Vesuvius.¬†
Or did he?¬†
Scholars disagree over whether the eruption of Vesuvius‚Äîand the disastrous burial and incineration of the ancient Roman city of Pompeii‚Äîoccurred in summer or fall. Here‚Äôs why some believe the eruption occurred in October, not August‚Äîand why the debate may never be settled.¬†
The August 24 date for the eruption of Mount Vesuvius comes from the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: This sacred site is one of the world‚Äôs oldest nature reserves
entry.summary:
Nomadic routes have been central to Mongolia since 3500 B.C., and some even later became part of the Silk Road. Mongolia‚Äôs Bogd Khan Uul was originally protected by an ally of Genghis Khan and is home to Bronze Age petroglyphs, breathtaking views, and ancient human settlements.
Where a family‚Äôs prized possessions are their cows and sheep, second only to the horses‚Äîand maybe a pair of binoculars‚Äîstrength has never been in numbers. The world‚Äôs last nomads have lived in harmony off the land for thousands of years in the least densely populated country in the world, but that is changing.
‚ÄúWe have never been team sports players because we can‚Äôt be,‚Äù explains Dorj Usukhjargal, a Mongolian biologist.
¬†On the Mongolian steppe, these minimalists race the horses they honor and eat ‚Ä¶

entry.title: A caffeine-fueled journey through Vietnam‚Äôs rich coffee culture
entry.summary:
Coffee is an essential beverage around the world, enjoyed as both a ritual, a social centerpiece, and a stimulant to face the day. In Italy, people enjoy¬†un caffe¬†standing at a bar, and in Senegal, vendors sell¬†spicy caf√© touba¬†at street-side shops called¬†tanganas. In Mexico City,¬†caf√© de olla¬†contains notes of cinnamon and cloves, and in Indonesia, brewers make¬†kopi joss¬†by plunging a piece of burning charcoal into iced coffee.¬†
Behind each distinctive cup is its history. Vietnam, in particular, has a storied past tied to the beverage that points to its resilience and ingenuity. First introduced by French missionaries in 1857, coffee‚Äôs success was due to Vietnamese laborers who cultivated Arabica. The bean didn‚Äôt fare well in the country‚Äôs climate, and the more flexible Robusta soo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside the sacred wolf hunts of western Mongolia
entry.summary:
As climate change affects their prey, wolves like this one in Mongolia‚Äôs Bayan-Olgiy Province have increasingly targeted the livestock of the region‚Äôs nomadic Kazakh herders‚Äîa community that venerates the species. High in the mountains, Kazakh herders have lived in careful balance with wolves for centuries. Now a celebrated tradition has become a matter of survival.
The horse‚Äôs body was still warm¬†when the three men came upon it in the snow. From only the wounds and a constellation of tracks around the horse, the trio of Kazakh herders could unspool the morning: A pair of wolves had jumped onto the horse‚Äôs upper back and brought it to its knees. Because its tender rear flank was missing‚Äîthe part a wolf might gorge on and then later regurgitate to a nursing mother tending to her you‚Ä¶

entry.title: This ancient human may be root of Homo sapiens family tree
entry.summary:
A handful of fossils (including this mandible) found in a cave in Casablanca, Morocco, belong to a previously unknown ancient group of hominins that are shaking up the tale of human origins.  New fossils unearthed in Morocco could help solve the mystery of how Homo sapiens diverged from other ancient humans like Neanderthals.
Around 770,000 years ago, a small windswept cave overlooked grassy plains and trees in what today is southwest Casablanca in Morocco. The area abounded with gazelle, hyena, antelope, mongoose, bears, the now-extinct giant gelada baboons‚Äîand a hitherto unknown group of early humans.
In a paper published today in the journal Nature, researchers report the discovery of new hominin fossils from this cave, called Grotte √† Hominid√©s, that date back to a cr‚Ä¶

entry.title: China asks tech firms to halt orders for Nvidia's H200 chips, Information reports
entry.summary: Beijing has asked some Chinese tech companies to halt orders for Nvidia's H200 chips this week and may mandate domestic AI chip purchases, the Information reported on Wednesday, citing people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: Cambodia says Chen Zhi among 3 extradited to China after transnational crime probe
entry.summary: Cambodia said on Wednesday it had extradited three people to China at the request of Beijing following a months-long joint investigation into transnational crime, among them an individual named Chen Zhi.

entry.title: Nestle infant formula recall widens to Africa, the Americas and Asia
entry.summary: Nestle's recall of some batches of infant nutrition products has widened beyond Europe to Africa, the Americas and Asia, including Brazil, China and South Africa, a tally from the company and national food safety statements show.

entry.title: HSG's continuation fund to value ByteDance at up to $370 billion, sources say
entry.summary: Venture capital firm HSG, formerly Sequoia Capital China, is raising a continuation fund that will take over some of its ByteDance shares at a valuation of between $350 billion and $370 billion, two people with knowledge of the matter said.

entry.title: Canada prime minister to visit China next week, spokesperson says
entry.summary: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney will visit China January 13-17, his office said on Wednesday, in what will be the first visit by a Canadian prime minister since 2017.

entry.title: China calls for joint counter-terrorism efforts with Pakistan
entry.summary: China is willing to intensify cooperation with Pakistan in fighting terrorism and telecom crime, Wang Xiaohong, China's public security minister, said in a meeting with Pakistan's interior and counter-narcotics minister in Beijing on Wednesday.

entry.title: Syria: Aleppo fighting leaves civilians dead, displaces thousands
entry.summary: At least five civilians have been killed and some 30,000 people displaced following renewed fighting in Aleppo, Syria, prompting calls from the UN for immediate de-escalation and a return to political talks.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Iraq ‚Äòunrecognisable and remarkable‚Äô after years of conflict: UN coordinator
entry.summary: Some two decades after a shaky political transition, Iraq today is a country ‚Äúat peace, with increased security and a clear determination to win the battle of development,‚Äù says the UN resident coordinator for Iraq on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: West Bank: UN report warns of ‚Äòsystematic asphyxiation‚Äô of Palestinian rights
entry.summary: A sweeping UN human rights report released on Wednesday concludes that in the occupied West Bank, Israel is violating international law prohibiting racial segregation and apartheid, warning that the discriminatory practices have accelerated dramatically since late 2022 amid growing violence, repression and impunity.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Drones, fear and exhaustion: The daily reality of providing aid to Ukraine
entry.summary: Almost four years since Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion of Ukraine, aid teams continue to adapt to the lethal reality of working in a modern war zone.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Brazil surpassing US as top beef producer, easing global supply squeeze
entry.summary: Brazil surpassed the U.S. as the world's top beef producer last year, according to market estimates, after the South American country beat output forecasts by hundreds of thousands of tons, easing a global supply squeeze and helping limit a surge in meat prices.

entry.title: Chinese refiners expected to replace Venezuelan oil with Iranian crude, traders say
entry.summary: Chinese independent refiners are expected to switch to heavy crude from sources including Iran in coming months to replace Venezuelan shipments halted since the U.S. removed the country's president, traders and analysts said.

entry.title: Trump's oil push widens with seizure of Russian-flagged tanker linked to Venezuela
entry.summary: The U.S. said it had seized a Russian-flagged, Venezuela-linked tanker as part of President Donald Trump's aggressive push to dictate oil flows in the Americas and force Caracas' socialist government to become its ally.

entry.title: China keen to revive food imports from Ireland, Irish PM says
entry.summary: China has signalled it would want to import quality food from Ireland, Irish Prime Minister Miche√°l Martin said about his meeting with Chinese Premier Li Qiang, who also pushed a message about China engaging with the European Union.

entry.title: China announces another new trade measure against Japan as tensions rise
entry.summary: China has escalated its trade tensions with Japan by launching an investigation into imported dichlorosilane, a chemical gas used in making semiconductors.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: China detains six underground church members in latest crackdown, church tells members
entry.summary: Six members of an influential underground Protestant church in China were detained by police this week, according to a church statement to members seen by Reuters and non-governmental organisations, in the latest crackdown on Chinese Christians.

entry.title: Printable calendar on a single page
entry.summary: NeatoCal is a JavaScript-based calendar implementation that you can print on a single‚Ä¶ Tags: calendar, JavaScript, print

entry.title: IKEA to close seven stores in China amid strategy shift
entry.summary: Furniture retailer IKEA is closing seven stores in China from February 2, it said in a statement on Wednesday.

entry.title: South Korean leader says he asked China‚Äôs Xi to act as mediator on North Korea issues
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung says he asked Chinese President Xi Jinping to serve as a mediator to help resolve the North Korean nuclear crisis and ease animosities between the two Koreas.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Rubio to meet Denmark leaders next week, signals no retreat on Trump's Greenland goal
entry.summary: A U.S. military seizure of the mineral-rich Arctic island from a longtime ally, Denmark, would send shock waves through the NATO alliance and deepen the divide between Trump and European leaders.

author.name: John Irish, Andreas Rinke, Anne Kauranen, Daphne Psaledakis

entry.title: Chinese smartphone maker Realme set to become an Oppo subbrand
entry.summary: Chinese smartphone maker Realme said on Wednesday that it was being integrated into Chinese consumer electronics company, Oppo, as a subbrand, in a move that aims to pool resources and cut costs for the two companies that share a parent firm.

entry.title: Xiaomi begins pre-orders for spruced up version of SU7 sedan, stresses safety features
entry.summary: China's Xiaomi began taking pre-orders on Wednesday for an upgraded version of its SU7 model, aiming to boost the popularity of the company's best-selling electric sedan in the highly competitive Chinese market.

entry.title: Morning Bid: The spoils of oil
entry.summary: A look at the day ahead in European and global markets from Rocky Swift

entry.title: South Korea's Lee says he asked Xi to play a mediating role on North Korea
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung said on Wednesday that much progress had been made in restoring trust with Beijing, and that he had asked Chinese President Xi Jinping to play a role in mediating Seoul's efforts to engage North Korea.

entry.title: Chinese AI server leader xFusion hires investment bank in first step toward listing
entry.summary: China's leading AI server provider xFusion has hired Citic Securities in preparation for an initial public offering, regulatory disclosure showed, adding the Huawei spin-off to a list of tech firms tapping investor fervour for AI.

entry.title: Taiwan says China's war games sought to undermine global support for the island
entry.summary: The drills were an attempt to divert attention away from Beijing's economic troubles, Taiwan's top security agency said.

entry.title: China's top diplomat heads to key strategic points in Africa
entry.summary: China's top diplomat began his annual New Year tour of Africa on Wednesday, with a focus on the strategically important east, as the world's No.2 economy seeks to reinforce its influence on the continent.

entry.title: Japan condemns China's dual-use export ban, rare earth risks loom
entry.summary: Japan said on Wednesday that China's ban on exports of dual-use items to the country was "absolutely unacceptable and deeply regrettable", as a diplomatic dispute between Asia's top two economies intensified.

entry.title: China bans two Taiwan ministers for alleged 'independence activities', angering Taipei
entry.summary: Beijing banned two Taiwanese ministers from entering China for alleged separatist activities related to Taiwan independence on Wednesday, prompting an angry response from Taipei, which said it would not bow to "threats and intimidation."

entry.title: Crude oil slumps, shares retreat as global tensions intensify
entry.summary: Crude futures slid and shares in Asia retreated as markets grappled with the ramifications of the political upheaval in Venezuela and the fate of its petroleum reserves.

entry.title: Lenovo expands AI lineup with Nvidia tie-up, Qira platform
entry.summary: China's Lenovo, , the world's largest personal computer maker, on Tuesday said it has teamed up with U.S. AI chip leader Nvidia to help AI cloud providers quickly put data centres into operation, as it strives to establish itself in AI.

entry.title: China reviews Meta's purchase of AI startup Manus, FT reports
entry.summary: Chinese officials are reviewing Meta's $2 billion acquisition of artificial intelligence startup Manus for possible technology control violations, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday, citing two people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: Why women may get more from exercise than men
entry.summary:
Recent studies suggest that women may gain comparable‚Äîor greater‚Äîcardiovascular benefits from physical activity than men, sometimes at lower weekly exercise levels. Emerging research suggests women‚Äôs cardiovascular systems may respond more strongly to physical activity than men‚Äôs, raising questions about how exercise guidelines are set.
For decades, exercise guidelines have treated men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs bodies as essentially the same. But new studies suggest that assumption may be wrong. Emerging evidence shows that women often experience greater reductions in heart disease and early death from physical activity than men, and may achieve those benefits with less weekly exercise. The findings are prompting researchers to reconsider how exercise recommendations are made, and whether one-‚Ä¶

entry.title: Period pain has long been ignored. That‚Äôs changing.
entry.summary:
When¬†Niara¬†Webb was 15 years old, she experienced period pain so debilitating that she passed out during a church service. When she came¬†to, she was surrounded by people who thought¬†she‚Äôd¬†experienced¬†a religious¬†awakening. ‚ÄúThe whole time I was just thinking,¬†I just need some Advil,‚Äù she remembers.¬†¬†
Now 27, Webb has experienced what she describes as ‚Äúhorrible‚Äù menstrual cramps since she first started her period. ‚ÄúI just lived a life of¬†my period cramps are just kind of bad, and that's how it is,‚Äù she says. Her experience is common: Dysmenorrhea, or painful periods,¬†affect¬†up to¬†91 percent¬†of individuals of reproductive age‚Äîwith¬†29 percent experiencing¬†‚Äúsevere‚Äù pain.¬†¬†
Webb suffers from secondary dysmenorrhea, when painful periods are a symptom of another health issue, like endom‚Ä¶

entry.title: See our favorite pictures of 2025 taken by ‚Ä¶ you
entry.summary:
The delicate West Indian seagrape sawfly (Sericoceros krugii) and its vibrant eggs highlight nature‚Äôs beauty in an urban setting, reminding me of the hidden wonders that often go unnoticed in our everyday lives. I captured this image in San Juan, Puerto Rico. These 10 standout images were among thousands of stunning submissions in National Geographic‚Äôs Your Shot Pictures of the Year 2025 challenge.
National Geographic is revealing our ten favorite photos from the Your Shot Picture of the Year 2025 challenge, chosen from thousands of stunning submissions.
Curated by National Geographic photo editor Anne Farrar, these favorites expose extraordinary encounters and show¬†the hidden beauty in our backyards.
‚ÄúThe process was both exciting and challenging,‚Äù says Farrar of selecti‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why this Japanese prefecture is obsessed with apples
entry.summary:
Hirosaki City Apple Park is home to as many as 2300 apple trees of around 80 varieties. In the northerly prefecture of Aomori, locals have a unique obsession with apples, which can be experienced in the region‚Äôs fields, bars and even onsens.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Manicured orchard rows fan out before me, branches heavy with picture-book apples in glistening lipstick red. Between the succession of trunks, tufts of grass are tickled by breeze; in the sky above, clouds drift by lazily. Green and pleasant, this scene could be mistaken for rural Britain ‚Äî but it‚Äôs actually northern Japan.
Think of Japanese produce, and rice, soybeans and wasabi spring to mind. But in the vast prefecture of Aomori, at the tip of the main island of Ho‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this photographer captured 129 portraits of fire survivors
entry.summary:
Gideon Mendel documented the moments when L.A. families returned to their fire-ravaged homes for the first time in early 2025. Hundreds of survivors responded to his call-out soliciting participants for this photo project. Photographer Gideon Mendel is no stranger to natural disasters.
The fires that tore through parts of Los Angeles last January were one of the worst natural disasters the city has experienced.¬†Estimates for just how much damage the fires cost¬†vary, but one figure ballparked¬†over¬†$130 billion¬†in property damage alone.¬†Victims of the fire returned to homes reduced to¬†rubble. Photographer Gideon Mendel was there to document those painful moments.¬†Over the course of five weeks, Mendel interviewed about four to five families a day.¬†Hi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Busting the 5 biggest myths about renewable energy
entry.summary:
Solar panels catch sunlight at an electric plant in southern Spain, 2008. From the scale of danger posed by wind turbines to the actual price of installing home solar panels, here are the facts you should know.
The past 10 years have been the hottest on record, a dramatic increase that has raised ocean temperatures and elevations, melted glaciers, and increased damage from natural disasters including hurricanes, floods, wildfires, and tornados‚Äîeffects that threaten wildlife species and human health.
Scientists are clear that reigning in the greenhouse gasses that are warming the planet require major shifts to renewable energies. Fortunately, the world is increasingly adopting these technologies. In 2025, coal dropped below renewables like solar and wind as the primary source o‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 of the best pizza spots that aren't in New York or Chicago
entry.summary:
Frank Pepe's in New Haven is Connecticut's oldest pizzeria. The restaurant celebrated irs 100th anniversary in 2025. If you‚Äôre in search of great pizza made with high-quality ingredients, here are seven places‚Äîfrom Oshkosh to Winston-Salem‚Äîthat are worth a trip.
New York City has more pizzerias with more variety than any other city in America. Meanwhile, Chicago has its own deep-dish style that no New York pizza spot has been able¬†to successfully replicate. Chicagoans can be as proud of their deep-dish favorites like Lou Malnati's and Gino's East as New Yorkers are of their favorite neighborhood joints, from New Park Pizza in Queens to L & B Spumoni Gardens in Brooklyn.
However, great pizza made with high-quality ingredients is no longer exclusively found in the large U.S. cit‚Ä¶

entry.title: Irish PM aims to discuss beef and dairy in Beijing trade talks
entry.summary: Ireland's Prime Minister Micheal Martin was to hold in-depth trade talks with Chinese Premier Li Qiang on Tuesday, aiming to strengthen strategic ties with the world's second-largest economy amid strained China-EU relations.

entry.title: How smart cities are being reinvented after natural disasters
entry.summary: Three hours before dawn¬†on February 6, 2023, a 29-year-old pastrymaker named Nuri Imren woke to the sound of his sister screaming. His family‚Äôs high-rise apartment in the Turkish city of Antakya was shaking violently‚Äîfirst from side to side, then up and down. A heavy wardrobe fell on his sister, pinning her under it and breaking her arm and shoulder. Imren, an amateur weight lifter, hurried into her room and raised the top of the wardrobe, resting it on his knees. A minute later, the shaking stopped and he was able to pull his sister free and usher her and their parents down 10 flights of stairs to the street. It was cold and dark outside, and a light rain was falling. All over the city, power was out. The darkness made it impossible to understand the devastation, but many of the eight- an‚Ä¶

entry.title: Dollar edges higher against peer currencies amid rate cut bets
entry.summary: The U.S. dollar edged higher against major peers on Tuesday, with the euro weighed down by softer inflation data, but moves were fairly muted with commodity and stock markets drawing most of the day's attention.

entry.title: Tesla UK car sales slump 29% in December as Chinese brands gain ground
entry.summary: Tesla's UK car registrations dropped by more than 29% year-on-year in December, industry data showed on Tuesday, underscoring the intense competition from Chinese rivals faced by the U.S. electric vehicle maker in its largest European market.

entry.title: Rockets, Mavs to play preseason games in Macao
entry.summary: The Dallas Mavericks and Houston Rockets will play two preseason games in Macao in October as part of the NBA China Games 2026.

entry.title: Italy closes probe into DeepSeek after commitments to warn of AI 'hallucination' risks
entry.summary: Italy‚Äôs antitrust authority has ended an investigation into the Chinese AI system DeepSeek for allegedly failing to warn users that it may produce false information, agreeing to binding commitments as a condition for closing the case.

entry.title: Nvidia CEO Huang to take stage at CES in Las Vegas as competition mounts
entry.summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is set to give a speech on Monday at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, potentially revealing new details about product plans for the world's most valuable listed company as it faces increasing competition from both rivals and its own customers.

entry.title: Dark sky retreats are on the rise‚Äîhere's where to take one
entry.summary:
Set in Northumberland's Dark Sky Park, Kielder Observatory is one of the UK's best places to watch the night unfold. Northumberland has some of the most pristine dark skies in Europe and a range of ways to enjoy them, from observatory tours to cosy forest cabins equipped with state-of-the-art telescopes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From the deck of Kielder Observatory, I look out across a sea of spruce, pine and larch overlaid by a slender film of mist. This is England‚Äôs largest forest, and in the soft light of a summer‚Äôs evening, it‚Äôs a mesmerising sight. But I‚Äôm not here to look out. I‚Äôm here to look up.
The observatory ‚Äî a stilted timber structure that feels like a bird hide hijacked by Scandi-chic architects ‚Äî is Northumberland‚Äôs‚Ä¶

entry.title: Mavericks, Rockets headed to China in October to play pair of preseason games
entry.summary: The NBA is heading back to China next season. The league announced Monday that the Dallas Mavericks and Houston Rockets will play preseason games in Macao in October.

entry.title: China and South Korea pledge to bolster ties as regional tensions rise
entry.summary: South Korea and China have pledged to boost trade and safeguard regional stability. This announcement came during South Korean President Lee Jae Myung's visit to Beijing on Monday.

entry.title: Russia loses ally in Venezuela but hopes to gain from Trump's 'Wild West' realpolitik
entry.summary: Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro's capture by the United States has deprived Vladimir Putin of an ally and could increase U.S. "oil clout", but Moscow is eying potential gains from President Donald Trump's division of the world into spheres of influence.

entry.title: China's oil investments in Venezuela
entry.summary: China is a major customer of and investor in Venezuela's oil sector, which President Donald Trump aims to revive following the U.S. military's ouster of President Nicolas Maduro on Saturday.

entry.title: Big adventures, small ships‚Äî26 of the best voyages to book for 2026
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Whether it‚Äôs exploring French Polynesia onboard a 230-passenger cargo ship, gliding along Sweden‚Äôs G√∂ta Canal in a 25-cabin, retro-inspired wooden boat or encountering the landscapes and wildlife of West Africa with only 50 other passengers, the small-scale cruise industry is booming. According to a recent study by CLIA, between 2023 and 2024, bookings for such voyages increased by 22%. With so much on offer, how can you know which expedition will be right for you? To help narrow the field, we‚Äôve selected 26 of the most exciting small-ship adventures for 2026 and beyond.
With more than 600 islands, 850 indigenous languages and 13,500 plant species, Papua New Guinea seriously impresses when it comes to diversity ‚Äî‚Ä¶

entry.title: What your grip strength reveals about how long you‚Äôll live
entry.summary:
Every time you twist open a jar, shake a hand, or squeeze a stress ball, you might be measuring something far more important than you realize: your future health. How firmly you can squeeze your hand provides clinicians with a snapshot into your overall health‚Äîwith studies consistently linking a strong grip to a healthier, longer life.
In twisting jar lids, carrying groceries, opening doors, and steadying ourselves during a stumble, most of us rely on grip strength far more often than we realize. But while these small movements rarely register as ‚Äúfitness,‚Äù a growing body of research suggests they offer a powerful glimpse into our overall wellbeing and how we‚Äôre aging.
‚ÄúHand grip strength is one of the most overlooked indicators of long-term health,‚Äù says Pete Rohleder, a kine‚Ä¶

entry.title: This asteroid is spilling secrets about how life on Earth began
entry.summary:
The OSIRIS-REx spacecraft spent two years observing the asteroid Bennu before it collected a sample in 2020. Grab-and-go missions to asteroids have provided some of the most scientifically valuable samples since the Apollo missions‚Äîand they‚Äôre shaking up the search for life beyond Earth.
On October 20, 2020, a robot carefully scooped up 121.6 grams of the most expensive dirt in the solar system.
That robot, a NASA spacecraft called OSIRIS-REx, had spent two years en route to its rendezvous with the near-earth asteroid Bennu and two more observing it. Its 1.16-billion-dollar mission: Recover a sample from Bennu‚Äôs strange surface of loosely-bound space pebbles and return it to Earth. It succeeded, and on September 24, 2023, OSIRIS-REx dropped its carefully-packed sample cap‚Ä¶

entry.title: How sunken ceramics ushered in a new era for archaeology
entry.summary:
This Campanian ceramic jar was brought up from a shipwreck near the French island of Grand Conglou√©, one of the first large-scale underwater archaeological excavations. Off the coast of Marseille, National Geographic Explorer Jacques-Yves Cousteau hauled up thousands of ancient clay vessels‚Äîand showed what fantastic discoveries modern scuba gear made possible.
Thousands of pieces of pottery like this one‚Äîcrafted in Campania, in what‚Äôs now southern Italy‚Äîfilled the hold of a wrecked Greek ship. The cargo went down in the western Mediterranean around 200 B.C., only to rise again a couple of millennia later thanks to Jacques-Yves Cousteau, famed oceanographer, scuba-gear pioneer, and National Geographic Explorer. In 1952, off a French islet near Marseille, his divers launched one of the world‚Äôs first underwater excavations, and the breadth of the haul was extraordinary. Alongside more than 7,000 ceramic pieces were some 2,000 clay jugs, called amphorae, once full of wine. (They‚Äôd belonged, archaeologists later realized, to two different ships wrecked at the same site.) When Cousteau found a single jug still sealed, he had the cork scraped away and poured out what a crewmate called a ‚Äúdark brown, thick, lumpy syrup.‚Äù Upon swigging the dregs of the ancient wine, Cousteau wrote, ‚ÄúI tasted all the mustiness and age there is in this world.‚Äù
See this object and more at the National Geographic Museum of Exploration starting summer 2026. Visit moe.nationalgeographic.org. A version of this story appears in the February 2026 issue of National Geographic magazine.

entry.title: The mystery man who claimed to be Marie-Antoinette‚Äôs son
entry.summary:
In a cemetery in the Dutch city of Delft, a simple tombstone bears a puzzling inscription.
‚ÄúHere Lies Louis XVII. Charles Louis, Duke of Normandy, King of France and of Navarre. Born at Versailles, March 27, 1785. Died at Delft, August 10, 1845.‚Äù
Puzzling, because the 10-year-old son of Louis XVI died in prison in Paris in 1795, less than two years after his mother, Marie-Antoinette, was executed at the Place de la Concorde. So why was his grave in the Netherlands? And why was his date of death listed as 1845, which would make the doomed queen's son 60 at the time of his passing?¬†
French journalists and historians often refer to the fate of Louis XVII as one of the ‚Äúgreatest enigmas‚Äù in the country‚Äôs history. Shadowy circumstances and unanswered questions surrounding the you‚Ä¶

entry.title: Maduro seized, norms tested: Security Council divided as Venezuela crisis deepens
entry.summary: The UN Security Council met on Monday against a sharply altered diplomatic backdrop, following US strikes on the Venezuelan capital and seizure of President Nicol√°s Maduro.

entry.title: Iran protests: UN warns against further bloodshed
entry.summary: As protests in the Iranian capital, Tehran ‚Äì sparked by increasing economic hardship and a cost-of-living crisis ‚Äì continued for a ninth day, the UN Secretary-General said he was ‚Äúdeeply saddened by the reported loss of life and injuries,‚Äù resulting from clashes between security forces and protesters.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: 100 per cent of basic food needs met for first time since 2023
entry.summary: For the first time since 2023, humanitarian assistance will provide Gazans with enough food to fulfil minimum nutritional needs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Escalating violence in Sudan, civilian danger grows in Ukraine, Ethiopia aid cuts
entry.summary: In Sudan, civilians continue to bear the brunt of escalating violence, particularly in the Darfur and Kordofan regions.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief deeply concerned over ‚Äòpossible intensification of instability‚Äô in Venezuela
entry.summary: Invoking the bedrock principle prohibiting the use of force against the territory and independence of any State, the UN Secretary-General told the Security Council on Monday there must be ‚Äúfull respect‚Äù for the UN Charter, in the face of the United States military intervention in Venezuela and seizure of President Nicol√°s Maduro.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: ‚ÄòThe power of the law must prevail,‚Äô says UN chief
entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting in emergency session in New York to address the US rendition of Venezuela‚Äôs President Nicol√°s Maduro from Caracas, a move that has sent shockwaves through the region and beyond. The UN chief Ant√≥nio Guterres told ambassadors there must be respect for national sovereignty, ‚Äúpolitical independence and territorial integrity,‚Äù after warning on Saturday that the US had set a ‚Äúdangerous precedent‚Äù for the world order. Follow the historic meeting live below from the UN Meetings Coverage team, and UN News app users can click here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: China's Zhou moves from Ferrari to Cadillac as F1 reserve
entry.summary: China's Zhou Guanyu has joined Cadillac from Ferrari as reserve driver for the Formula One debutants this season, the General Motors-backed team announced on Monday.

entry.title: Tencent-backed fintech Airwallex to invest in the Netherlands
entry.summary: Australian payment firm Airwallex said on Monday it will invest around 200 million euros ($233.64 million) over the next five years in its Netherlands operations, marking a major European expansion as it shifts from its Asia-Pacific base.

entry.summary: A look at the day ahead in U.S. and global markets by Dhara Ranasinghe.

entry.summary: ÁæéÂõΩÊÄªÁªü Donald Trump Âú®Êñ∞Âπ¥ÂÅáÊúüÂêéËøîÂõûÁôΩÂÆ´ÔºåÂçéÁõõÈ°øÁâπÂå∫„ÄÇ1Êúà4Êó•ÔºåÂçéÁõõÈ°ø„ÄÅÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶„ÄÅËäùÂä†Âì•„ÄÅÊ≥¢Â£´È°øÁ≠âÂÖ®ÁæéË∂ÖËøá100‰∏™ÂüéÂ∏ÇÁàÜÂèëÂèçÊàòÁ§∫Â®ÅÊ¥ªÂä®ÔºåÊäóËÆÆÁæéÂõΩÊîøÂ∫úÂØπÂßîÂÜÖÁëûÊãâÂèëÂä®ÂÜõ‰∫ãË¢≠ÂáªÔºåË¶ÅÊ±ÇÁ´ãÂç≥ÂÅúÊ≠¢Êàò‰∫âÂπ∂ÈáäÊîæÂßîÂÜÖÁëûÊãâÊÄªÁªü Nicolas Maduro„ÄÇÂßîÂÜÖÁëûÊãâÊÄªÁªü Maduro ÁõÆÂâçË¢´ÂÖ≥ÊäºÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â§ßÈÉΩ‰ºöÊãòÁïô‰∏≠ÂøÉÔºåÁæéÂõΩÂè∏Ê≥ïÈÉ®Ëµ∑ËØâÂÖ∂ÁäØÊúâÊØíÂìÅÊÅêÊÄñ‰∏ª‰πâ„ÄÅËµ∞ÁßÅÂèØÂç°Âõ†„ÄÅÊåÅÊúâÊú∫Êû™ÂèäÁ†¥ÂùèÊÄßË£ÖÁΩÆÁ≠â4È°πÁΩ™ÂêçÔºåÈ¢ÑËÆ°Â∞Ü‰∫é1Êúà5Êó•Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Âá∫Â∏≠Â∫≠ÂÆ°„ÄÇÊëÑÂΩ±Â∏àÔºöAlex Wong

entry.title: South Korea's Lee seeks to develop strategic cooperative partnership with China
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung told Chinese President Xi Jinping on Monday their summit is an important opportunity for full restoration of South Korea-China relations.

entry.title: Hungary's Orban says US intervention in Venezuela good for energy markets
entry.summary: The U.S. decision to topple Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro should have a positive impact on world energy markets, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban said on Monday, adding that the U.S. and Venezuela would control up to half of global oil reserves.

entry.title: Oil flotilla sails from Venezuela despite US blockade
entry.summary: About a dozen oil tankers loaded with Venezuelan crude and fuel have left the country's waters since the start of the year in apparent defiance of the U.S. government's blockade on exports, according to documents seen by Reuters and industry sources including monitoring service TankerTrackers.com.

entry.title: China nudges banks to disclose lending ties with Venezuela, Bloomberg News reports
entry.summary: China's top financial regulator asked its policy banks and other major lenders to report their lending exposure to Venezuela after the U.S. capture of the Venezuelan president, Bloomberg News reported on Monday, citing people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: China, Pakistan reaffirm ties as US outreach to Islamabad deepens
entry.summary: China and Pakistan pledged on Monday to further deepen ties and expand cooperation, reaffirming to each other their historically "ironclad" friendship as signs of rapprochement between Islamabad and Washington grow.

entry.title: Honda extends China plants suspension on chip shortage
entry.summary: Honda Motor said on Monday it will extend a production halt at three car plants in China by two weeks due to a semiconductor shortage, highlighting persistent supply chain strains for Japan's second-biggest automaker.

entry.title: Chinese cyberattacks on Taiwan infrastructure averaged 2.6 million a day in 2025, report says
entry.summary: Some were synchronised with military drills in "hybrid threats" to paralyse the island, Taiwan's National Security Bureau said.

entry.title: China seeks to enhance ties with Ireland to boost relations with EU
entry.summary: China is keen on expanding economic and trade cooperation with Ireland while aiming for mutually beneficial results, Chinese President Xi Jinping told the Irish prime minister on Monday, positioning stronger bilateral ties as a way to also boost relations with the European Union.

entry.title: Exclusive: Samsung to double AI mobile devices to 800 million units this year
entry.summary: Samsung seeks to reclaim its lost crown from Apple in the smartphone market and fend off competition from Chinese rivals.

entry.title: Korea's Lee, in Beijing, sees full restoration of China ties in 2026
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung said on Monday that he wants to open a "new phase" for relations with China, after meeting with President Xi Jinping during Lee's first trip to Beijing since taking office in June.

entry.title: China's services growth hits 6-month low in December, shows private PMI
entry.summary: China's services activity expanded at its slowest pace in six months in December, as growth in new business softened and foreign demand declined, a private-sector survey showed on Monday.

entry.title: China says it cannot accept countries acting as 'world judge' after US captures Maduro
entry.summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said Beijing cannot accept any country acting as the "world's judge" after the United States captured Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro.

entry.title: North Korea test-fires hypersonic missiles, KCNA says
entry.summary: North Korea test-fired hypersonic missiles on Sunday, state media KCNA reported on Monday, to assess its military operational capability regarding war deterrence.

entry.title: Deep in polar bear territory‚Äîsail to Greenland's eastern fjords
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre deep in polar bear territory now.‚Äù The expedition leader‚Äôs voice bounces off the icebergs, echoing around the bay before the glacier swallows it whole. Moving clumsily through the water in my kayak, I feel vulnerable, hunted, a¬†paddling nugget in a neon-yellow drysuit that barely wards off the biting wind and needling rain. ‚ÄúThey can swim hundreds of miles without stopping,‚Äù Ilene Price continues cheerfully, doing nothing to dispel my nerves. I scan the icebergs, which bloom improbably from the slate-grey water, forming a spectacular sculpture park ‚Äî¬†the perfect stage for a game of cat and mouse.
Clouds hang low and heavy, snagging on basalt peaks black as obsidian and close enough to our kayaks that I can s‚Ä¶

entry.title: North Korea condemns US strikes on Venezuela as 'serious encroachment of sovereignty'
entry.summary: North Korea has denounced the U.S. strikes on Venezuela as "the most serious form of encroachment of sovereignty," state news agency KCNA said on Sunday.

entry.title: US strike will embolden China's territorial claims, analysts say
entry.summary: The U.S. attack on Venezuela will embolden China to strengthen its territorial claims over areas such as Taiwan and parts of the South China Sea but will not hasten any potential invasion of Taiwan, analysts said.

entry.title: In a frozen northeastern Chinese city, an annual ode to ice rises
entry.summary: Each January, a strange and beautiful thing happens in the frigid northern Chinese city of Harbin. Some would argue that the place has enough ice already.

entry.title: South Korea's Lee begins China state visit after North fires missiles
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung began a state visit to China on Sunday, hoping to promote peace on the Korean Peninsula hours after rival North Korea launched ballistic missiles.

entry.title: South Korean president visits China following Beijing‚Äôs rising tensions with Japan over Taiwan
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung is set to visit China on Sunday as Beijing aims to strengthen ties amid heightened tensions with Japan over Taiwan.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: North Korea launches ballistic missiles toward sea ahead of South Korean leader‚Äôs visit to China
entry.summary: South Korea says North Korea has launched ballistic missiles toward the sea. South Korea‚Äôs Joint Chiefs of Staff says it detected several ballistic missile launches from North Korea‚Äôs capital region Sunday morning, hours before South Korea‚Äôs president left for China for talks.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: North Korea fires ballistic missiles as rival South's leader visits China
entry.summary: North Korea launched ballistic missiles on Sunday, the day the leader of rival South Korea starts a state visit to China, Pyongyang's chief ally, and just hours after the U.S. attacked Venezuela.

entry.title: A guide to Cambridge, the historic UK university city
entry.summary:
King‚Äôs College was founded in 1441 by King Henry VI as a 'finishing school' for scholars from Eton College. With its exquisite architecture, eclectic museums and cosy pubs, this charming university city is a welcoming place to while away a weekend during the colder months.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Compact Cambridge has an inordinately high concentration of beauty. Though only an hour north east of London, the fenland city seems to belong to another age entirely ‚Äî its gloriously unmodernised centre chock-a-block with soaring spires, historic colleges and cycling students trailing long scarves. Life centres around the university ‚Äî one of the world‚Äôs oldest and most prestigious, with more epoch-defining alumni than most people have had ho‚Ä¶

entry.summary: Ireland's Prime Minister Miche√°l Martin visits China starting Sunday, marking the first visit by an Irish leader in 14 years.

entry.title: Irish PM Martin to visit China as Beijing shores up EU ties
entry.summary: Irish Prime Minister Miche√°l Martin will visit China from Sunday, the Asian nation's foreign ministry said, the first such trip by an Irish Taoiseach since 2012 as Beijing shores up ties with individual members of the European Union bloc.

entry.title: Trump blocks chips deal, cites security, China-related concerns
entry.summary: President Donald Trump on Friday blocked U.S. photonics firm HieFo Corp's $3 million acquisition of assets in New Jersey-based aerospace and defense specialist Emcore, citing national security and China-related concerns.

entry.title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un visits greenhouse farm, encourages workers, KCNA says
entry.summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un inspected a greenhouse farm construction site along the country's border with China on Friday, and encouraged youths and troops working on the construction in the new year, state media KCNA said on Saturday.

entry.title: Italy's new car sales down 2.12% in 2025 as Chinese brands gain market share
entry.summary: Sales of new cars in Italy fell by 2.12% last year to 1.53 million units with Chinese brand BYD performing strongly, transport ministry data showed on Friday.

entry.title: Tesla loses EV crown to China's BYD as competition, tax credit expiry hit demand
entry.summary: Tesla ceded its crown as the world's top electric vehicle maker to China's BYD after annual sales fell for a second year, with intensifying competition, the expiration of U.S. tax credits and damage to the automaker's brand hurting demand.
